awd_titl_txt: DMREF/GOALI: Integrated Framework for Design of Alloy-Oxide Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Nearly every metal and alloy system is susceptible to reaction with air to form an oxide. The oxidation processes leading to scale formation often occur in an uncontrolled manner, resulting in corrosion and metal degradation. In some instances, however, oxidation can be managed in a way to produce a protective scale that makes the alloy resistant to degradation in reactive environments. The oxidation of metals and alloys can also be exploited as routes to synthesizing new materials for wide ranging functional applications such as catalysts, Li-ion batteries and photovoltaics. Oxidation is among the most challenging non-equilibrium processes to model and predict. This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) award supports basic research directed at developing the scientific foundation necessary to predict oxidation of high performance alloys. It will lead to the development of a suite of integrated modeling and experimental tools that will enable the rational and directed design of superior alloys for wide ranging aerospace, automotive, biomedical and energy conversion applications. The close collaboration with ATI, a leading manufacturer of advanced alloys, will ensure that the scientific outcomes of this project have a viable path for impacting technology. This work will impact education, science, and technology in a cross-cutting effort by:  1) providing an open framework integrating theory, experiment and computation to enable the design of higher-performance alloys with controlled oxidation behavior; 2) exposing students and professionals to cutting-edge modeling, synthesis and characterization tools, thereby preparing them for future careers in STEM fields; and 3) impacting other fields where oxidation and corrosion are significant issues. The program will promote the participation of students and professionals from underrepresented groups in an open learning setting.  

Non-equilibrium materials processes such as the oxidation of metals and alloys remain poorly understood and lack robust theories that link macroscopic behavior to properties at the electronic structure scale. This research program seeks to develop and apply a framework that integrates first-principles statistical mechanics approaches, continuum mechanics, phase transformation simulation tools and state-of-the-art experiment to enable (i) the discovery of predictive theories of non-equilibrium processes such as oxidation and (ii) the rational and directed design of new alloys with controlled oxidation behavior. Computational approaches will be developed that link the atomic and electronic structure scales with the continuum scales. These approaches will be tightly integrated with experiment (synthesis and characterization), which will serve to validate predictions and inform model/theory development. The resultant multi-scale infrastructure will enable the development of a mechanistic understanding of non-equilibrium processes and will be applied in a study of the oxidation of Ti alloys to generate the scientific knowledge base and understanding needed to design alloys that have prescribed oxidation behavior. This activity, in collaboration with the industrial partner, will lay the scientific foundation to enable the design of new Ti alloys that form protective scales and that are not susceptible to oxide decomposition and dissolution reactions due to the highly reactive nature of Ti.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The oxidation of metallic alloys is a complex non-equilibrium process of tremendous importance to many technological applications. Oxidation processes are challenging to model rigorously, especially when multiple reaction products are feasible and when accompanied by oxygen permeation into the metal substrate, as in the case of the early transition metals (Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta).  The problem is rich in scientific issues arising from the interplay of thermodynamics and kinetics, both within the alloy as well as in the oxide scale.  The objective of this DMREF project has been to develop a first-principles multi-scale framework that is integrated with experiment to enable the prediction of the dynamic evolution of complex materials systems. While this framework is applicable to a wide range of non-equilibrium phenomena, the focus of the project was on oxidation processes of titanium and its alloys. The high specific strength and corrosion resistance of Ti alloys make them important materials for aerospace applications, while their biocompatibility makes them well suited for biomedical implants. The oxides of Ti are also attractive materials for photocatalysis and Li-ion batteries.

New multi-scale modeling tools that leverage advances in machine learning were developed as part of the project. The developed framework starts from the electronic structure and extends to the continuum phenomenological level, using statistical mechanics to account for the role of temperature and entropy. Combined computational and experimental studies of oxidation processes of Ti and its alloys enabled the development of fundamental insights about oxidation mechanisms, high temperature thermodynamic properties of Ti alloys and the electronic structure of Ti alloys in the presence of dissolved oxygen.

Specific project outcomes include:

-       A comprehensive first-principles statistical mechanics study of the Ti-Al-O ternary system that led to the discovery of a strong short-range repulsive interaction between dissolved oxygen and aluminum within Ti that has significant repercussion on high temperature thermodynamic properties.

-       A generalization of the insights developed for the Ti-Al-O ternary to other Ti alloys with the discovery of similar repulsive interactions between dissolved oxygen and most substitutional alloying elements and the development of a fundamental understanding about the role of the unique electronic structure of Ti in causing this short-range repulsion.

-       The development of a new multi-scale approach that links first-principles statistical mechanics with phase field models of microstructure evolution using machine learning techniques and adaptive learning approaches to represent free energies in high dimensional order-parameter spaces.

-       The development of algorithms and software to identify crystallographic pathways during structural transformations and to measure the similarity between different crystal structures.  

-       New insights were developed experimentally about the effect of Nb and Si alloying elements on the oxidation behavior of Ti-Nb and Ti-Si alloys. Contrary to conventional wisdom, it was demonstrated that oxygen can be used as a deliberate alloying element to enhance the mechanical properties of Ti-alloys.

-       The training of graduate students in a new paradigm of materials research that involves an iterative feedback loop between modeling, characterization and synthesis.

-       The results of experimental, methodological and computational efforts, which were disseminated over seventeen archival peer reviewed publications.

-       The project supported contributions to three open-source software packages (CASM, mechanoChem, MultiShifter) that aim to predict thermodynamic and kinetic properties of materials starting from first principles.

The project has had broader impacts on education, science, and technology by: 1) enabling the development of a computational infrastructure to model non-equilibrium materials processes starting from the electronic structure; 2) introducing a framework that integrates computation, synthesis and characterization to aid the design of higher-performance alloys; 3) preparing students and professionals for future careers in Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME); 4) impacting other fields where non-equilibrium process are significant issues (e.g. battery materials, electrochemistry, alloy processing); and 5) promoting participation of students and professionals from under-represented groups in a multidisciplinary and collaborative setting that mixes fundamental and applied work.
